tit.cmt: タイトルのため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 典薬寮（てんやくりょう）は、律令制により制定された機関で、宮内省律令制度下に属する医療・調薬を担当する部署。
sen.e: The Tenyakuryo was an institution established under Japan's Ritsuryo system; specifically, it was under the purview of the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Agency) of the Ritsuryo system, and was the bureau responsible for giving medical care and providing doses of medicine.

The Tenyakuryo was an institution established under Japan's Ritsuryo system; specifically, it was under the purview of the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Agency) of the Ritsuryo system, and was the bureau responsible for giving medical care and providing doses of medicine.

The Tenyakuryo (Bureau of Medicine) was an institution established under Japan's Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code); specifically, it was under the purview of the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Agency) of the Ritsuryo system, and was the bureau responsible for giving medical care and providing doses of medicine.
sen.cmt: 律令制 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 典薬寮は宮廷官人への医療、医療関係者の養成および薬園等の管理を行った。
sen.e: Those working at the Tenyakuryo provided medical care--and trained those who offered such care--for the officials at court, as well as overseeing gardens of medicinal herbs and other such projects.
Those working at the Tenyakuryo provided medical care--and trained those who offered such care--for the officials at court, as well as overseeing gardens of medicinal herbs and other such projects.
Those working at the Tenyakuryo provided medical care--and trained those who offered such care--for the officials at court, as well as overseeing gardens of medicinal herbs and other such projects.

sen.j: 天皇への医療を行う内薬司と対を成す。
sen.e: The Tenyakuryo formed a counterpart with the Naiyakushi, who were responsible for providing medical care to the Emperor himself.
The Tenyakuryo formed a counterpart with the Naiyakushi, who were responsible for providing medical care to the Emperor himself.
The Tenyakuryo formed a counterpart with the Naiyakushi, who were responsible for providing medical care to the Emperor himself.

sen.j: 896年に内薬司を併合して朝廷の医療を掌握した。
sen.e: In 896, the Tenyakuryo absorbed the Kunaishi, seizing a monopoly over all the court's medical needs.
In 896, the Tenyakuryo absorbed the Kunaishi, seizing a monopoly over all the court's medical needs.
In 896, the Tenyakuryo absorbed the Naiyakushi, seizing a monopoly over all the court's medical needs.

sen.j: 長官は典薬頭で、典医、針師、按摩師、呪禁師で構成されていた。
sen.e: The bureau's head was called the Tenyaku no kami, and the rest of the bureau's personnel was organized into teni (doctors), harishi (acupuncturists), anmashi (masseurs), and jugonshi (sorcerer-physicians).

The bureau's head was called the Tenyaku no kami, and the rest of the bureau's personnel was organized into teni (doctors), harishi (acupuncturists), anmashi (masseurs), and jugonshi (sorcerer-physicians).

The bureau's head was called the Tenyaku no kami, and the rest of the bureau's personnel was organized into teni (doctors), harishi (acupuncturists), anmashi (masseurs), and jugonshi (sorcerer-physicians).

sen.j: また、医博士、針博士、按摩博士、呪禁博士、薬園師がおり、その下には学生である医得業生が学んでいた。
sen.e: There were also ihakase (Masters of medicine), harihakase (Masters of acupuncture), anmahakase (Masters of massage), jugonhakase (Masters of healing magic), and yakuenshi (instructors in growing medicinal herb gardens), under whom the bureau's students, called Itokugyosho (distinguished scholars of medicine), learned.

There were also ihakase (Masters of medicine), harihakase (Masters of acupuncture), anmahakase (Masters of massage), jugonhakase (Masters of healing magic), and yakuenshi (instructors in growing medicinal herb gardens), under whom the bureau's students, called Itokugyosho (distinguished scholars of medicine), learned.

There were also ihakase (Masters of medicine), harihakase (Masters of acupuncture), anmahakase (Masters of massage), jugonhakase (Masters of healing magic), and yakuenshi (an official in charge of managing medicinal-herb garden), under whom the bureau's students, called Itokugyosho (distinguished scholars of medicine), learned.
sen.cmt: 薬園師 補足を変更しました。

sen.j: 内薬司併合時には侍医・薬生・女医博士も移管された。
sen.e: At the time of the bureau's absorption of the Naiyakushi, control over the jii (the physicians for the Emperor and Imperial family), students of medicine, and Joihakase (female Masters of medicine) was also transferred to the Tenyakuryo.

At the time of the bureau's absorption of the Naiyakushi, control over the jii (the physicians for the Emperor and Imperial family), students of medicine, and Joihakase (female Masters of medicine) was also transferred to the Tenyakuryo.

At the time of the bureau's absorption of the Naiyakushi, control over the jii (the physicians for the Emperor and Imperial Family), Yakusei (students of medicine), and Joihakase (female Masters of medicine) was also transferred to the Tenyakuryo.
sen.cmt: 薬生 追加しました。

sen.j: 平安時代後期以降、和気氏と丹波氏による世襲となり、典薬頭は専ら丹波氏の小森家が独占した。
sen.e: Starting in the late Heian period, appointment to the bureau became a hereditary privilege of the Wake and Tanba clans, and the Komori family of the Tanba clan achieved a complete monopoly over the position of Tenyaku no kami.

Starting in the late Heian period, appointment to the bureau became a hereditary privilege of the Wake and Tanba clans, and the Komori family of the Tanba clan achieved a complete monopoly over the position of Tenyaku no kami.

Starting in the late Heian period, appointment to the bureau became a hereditary privilege of the Wake and Tanba clans, and the Komori family of the Tanba clan achieved a complete monopoly over the position of Tenyaku no kami.

sen.j: 小森家は六位蔵人を兼ねたため、典薬頭であっても実際の天皇の拝診には携わらない事務職的存在となった。
sen.e: But because the Komori family at that time were only Kurodo of the Sixth Rank, even as the Tenyaku no kami they were too low-ranked to take part in the actual medical examinations given to the Emperor, meaning their job was limited to more clerical and adminstrative duties.

But because the Komori family at that time were only Kurodo of the Sixth Rank, even as the Tenyaku no kami they were too low-ranked to take part in the actual medical examinations given to the Emperor, meaning their job was limited to more clerical and adminstrative duties.

But because the Komori family at that time were only Rokui no Kurodo (Chamberlain of Sixth Rank), even as the Tenyaku no kami (the head of Tenyakuryo) they were too low-ranked to take part in the actual medical examinations given to the Emperor, meaning their job was limited to more clerical and administrative duties.
sen.cmt: 六位蔵人 典薬頭 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: また、典薬権助の地位は賀茂別雷神社の社家である藤木家が世襲したが、こちらは実際に鍼を行い、天皇の診察もする家系であった。
sen.e: The position of Tenyaku gon no suke (Assistant Chief) was also hereditary, resting with the Fujiki family, a family of Shinto priests who oversaw Kamo Wakeikazuchi Jinja shrine, but those holding this position actually performed acupuncture, and were one of the family lineages permitted to perform medical examinations of the Emperor.

The position of Tenyaku gon no suke (Assistant Chief) was also hereditary, resting with the Fujiki family, a family of Shinto priests who oversaw Kamo Wakeikazuchi Jinja shrine, but those holding this position actually performed acupuncture, and were one of the family lineages permitted to perform medical examinations of the Emperor.

The position of Tenyaku gon no suke (assistant chief of Tenyakuryo) was also hereditary, resting with the Fujiki family, a family of Shinto priests who oversaw Kamo Wakeikazuchi Jinja Shrine, but those holding this position actually performed acupuncture, and were one of the family lineages permitted to perform medical examinations of the Emperor.
sen.cmt: Shrine 大文字にしました。

sen.j: 江戸時代に至っては、京都や諸国の優秀な民間医が官位を与えられて典薬寮医師（御典医）に登用されるケースが多くなり、典薬大允以下の役職は、典医の中から技術の優劣や年功の長幼によって選ばれた。
sen.e: Leading up into the Edo period, there were many cases where the most outstanding private civilian doctors in Kyoto and the other provinces were given office and rank and appointed as Tenyakuryo physicians (goteni); candidates--both young and old--for official posts of Tenyaku Taijo rank or lower were chosen from among the teni (doctors) either due to their superior skills or due to a long record of distinguished service.

Leading up into the Edo period, there were many cases where the most outstanding private civilian doctors in Kyoto and the other provinces were given office and rank and appointed as Tenyakuryo physicians (goteni); candidates--both young and old--for official posts of Tenyaku Taijo rank or lower were chosen from among the teni (doctors) either due to their superior skills or due to a long record of distinguished service.

Leading up into the Edo period, there were many cases where the most outstanding private civilian doctors in Kyoto and the other provinces were given office and rank and appointed as Tenyakuryo physicians (goteni); candidates--both young and old--for official posts of Tenyaku Taijo (Senior Secretary of the Bureau of Medicine) rank or lower were chosen from among the teni (doctors) either due to their superior skills or due to a long record of distinguished service.
sen.cmt: 典薬大允 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代の後期になると、伝統的な漢方医学に加え、伊良子光顕などオランダ医学の流れを汲む者も登用されるようになった。
sen.e: Towards the end of the Edo period, a new type of doctor was added to those practicing traditional Chinese medicine, and its practitioners began to be appointed to the Tenyakuryo: this type comprised doctors, for example Mitsuaki IRAKO, who followed the trends in Western (specifically, Dutch) medicine.

Towards the end of the Edo period, a new type of doctor was added to those practicing traditional Chinese medicine, and its practitioners began to be appointed to the Tenyakuryo: this type comprised doctors, for example Mitsuaki IRAKO, who followed the trends in Western (specifically, Dutch) medicine.

Towards the end of the Edo period, a new type of doctor was added to those practicing traditional Chinese medicine, and its practitioners began to be appointed to the Tenyakuryo: this type comprised doctors, for example Mitsuaki IRAKO, who followed the trends in Western (specifically, Dutch) medicine.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、明治維新に伴う官制改革によって廃止されたが、律令制に基づく機関の中では、最後まで設置当初の職掌を名実ともに保った稀有の存在であった。
sen.e: In 1869, the Tenyakuryo was abolished during the reform of government institutions that followed the Meiji Restoration, but among all the institutions based on the ritsuryo system, the Tenyakuryo had the rare distinction of having managed to maintain, both in word and in deed, its official functions from when it was founded right up until the moment it was dissolved.

In 1869, the Tenyakuryo was abolished during the reform of government institutions that followed the Meiji Restoration, but among all the institutions based on the ritsuryo system, the Tenyakuryo had the rare distinction of having managed to maintain, both in word and in deed, its official functions from when it was founded right up until the moment it was dissolved.

In 1869, the Tenyakuryo was abolished during the reform of government institutions that followed the Meiji Restoration, but among all the institutions based on the ritsuryo system, the Tenyakuryo had the rare distinction of having managed to maintain, both in word and in deed, its official functions from when it was founded right up until the moment it was dissolved.

tit.e: The Nyugyuin (the Cowsmilk Office, in charge of raising milkcows and providing their milk to the Imperial family)
The Nyugyuin (the Cowsmilk Office, in charge of raising milkcows and providing their milk to the Imperial family)
tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、補足は削除しました。

sen.j: 乳牛院は典薬寮に付属した機関の一つ。
sen.e: The Nyugyuin was one of the offices under the purview of the Tenyakuryo.
The Nyugyuin was one of the offices under the purview of the Tenyakuryo.
The Nyugyuin (the Cowsmilk Office, in charge of raising milkcows and providing their milk to the Imperial Family) was one of the offices under the purview of the Tenyakuryo.
sen.cmt: 乳牛院 の補足をこちらに追加しました。

sen.j: 平安時代に設置された。
sen.e: It was founded during the Heian period.
It was founded during the Heian period.
It was founded during the Heian period.

sen.j: 別当が総監し乳師長上に統轄された品部の乳戸が乳牛の飼育、牛乳の採取を行って皇室に供御した。
sen.e: The office's Betto (head) managed the office overall, while the Nyuko of the Shinabe (technicians) under the supervision of the Nyushichojo reared cattle, and cowsmilk was then selected and presented to the Imperial family for their meals.
sen.cmt: The original sentence in Japanese is so poorly written, and filled with so many technical terms, that it is essentially unintelligible.
sen.e: The office's Betto (head) managed the office overall, while the Nyuko of the Shinabe (technicians) under the supervision of the Nyushichojo reared cattle, and cowsmilk was then selected and presented to the Imperial family for their meals.

The office's Betto (head) managed the office overall, while the Nyuko (dairy farmer) of the Shinabe (technicians) under the supervision of the Nyushichojo reared cattle, and cowsmilk was then selected and presented to the Imperial Family for their meals.
sen.cmt: 乳戸 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 牛乳や蘇・醍醐は薬としても使われていた。
sen.e: Cowsmilk, along with shiso and daigo (both dairy products somewhat similar to cheese), were also used for medicinal purposes.
sen.cmt: I thought the character glossed as "shiso" was actually simply "so", as seen in: http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%98%87.
sen.e: Cowsmilk, along with shiso and daigo (both dairy products somewhat similar to cheese), were also used for medicinal purposes.
Cowsmilk, along with so and daigo (both dairy products somewhat similar to cheese), were also used for medicinal purposes.

sen.j: 頭（従五位下）
sen.e: The Kashira (head), of fifth rank, junior grade
The Kashira (head), of fifth rank, junior grade
The Kashira (head), of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade)

sen.j: 助（従六位従六位） 権助
sen.e: Suke (deputy chief), of junior sixth rank, and the Gon no suke (deputy to the deputy chief)
sen.cmt: Beginning here, each sentence contains an apparently superfluous "jurokui", which I have ignored in the translation.
sen.e: Suke (deputy chief), of junior sixth rank, and the Gon no suke (deputy to the deputy chief)

Harishi (acupuncturists), of senior eighth rank, responsible for providing medical treatment by acupuncture and moxibustion

sen.j: 呪禁師（従六位正八位） 呪文等によって治療・陰陽寮に職掌を奪われて消滅
sen.e: Jugonshi (sorcerer-physicians), of senior eighth rank, who attempted to heal patients using incantations; jugonshi disappeared from the Tenyakuryo after their official duties were usurped by the Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination).

Jugonshi (sorcerer-physicians), of senior eighth rank, who attempted to heal patients using incantations; jugonshi disappeared from the Tenyakuryo after their official duties were usurped by the Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination).

Yakusei, in charge of preparing medicine; control over this position was transferred to the Tenyakuryo from the Naiyakushi.
